did.abstract: Professor of psychology at the University of Michigan, known for his work in social psychology, organizational behavior and race relations; papers document his teaching and research activities 1925-1997, and involvement in professional organizations.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection was received in three accessions, the first as part of the University of Michigan Department of Psychology record group, (Donor no. 5883) the second from Jean Katz Corwardine and Joanna Katz (Donor no. 8715, and the third form Katz's office at the Institute for Social Research (Donor no. 7399).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Daniel Katz papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: University of Michigan psychology professor Daniel Katz was a nationally recognized scholar in the fields of social psychology and organizational behavior; he also made major contributions to the study of national attitudes and race relations. He is perhaps best known as the co-author (with Robert L. Kahn) of The Social Psychology of Organizations, which was published in 1966 and is widely considered to have been a seminal work in the discipline of social psychology.

Katz was born in Trenton, New Jersey on July 19, 1903. He received his BA from the University of Buffalo in 1925, and then enrolled at Syracuse University where he earned an MA in 1926 and a Ph.D. in Social Psychology in 1928. He married Christine Ross Braley in 1930, and they had two daughters.

Between 1928 and 1943, Katz was on the faculty of Princeton University's Psychology Department; he left in 1943 to become the first chairman of the Department of Psychology at Brooklyn College. During the Second World War he served as research director for the Division of Surveys of the Office of War Information, and as a research analyst for the War Department. Katz and a number of the social scientists he worked with during the war years formed the core of the Institute for Social Research (ISR) at the University of Michigan.

In 1947, Katz became director of ISR, where he researched human relations and management practices, including the role of worker participation in decision-making. Simultaneously, Katz became a professor of psychology. With Theodore Newcomb, he was instrumental in developing Michigan's doctoral program in social psychology. The Katz-Newcomb Lecture, an annual University event established in 1970, honors both professors.

Professor Katz carried out much of his research abroad, visiting Norway as a Fulbright scholar in 1951, and returning as a National Science Foundation Senior Fellow in 1957. As part of "A Study of National Attitudes and Values," Katz worked at the Belgrade Center from 1968 to 1969, where he directed field surveys in four Yugoslav republics. He also worked in Greece during this period, and was visiting professor at the University of Aarhus, Denmark from 1971 to 1972.

Over the course of his career, Katz published numerous articles and co-authored several books. He also edited or served on the editorial board of a variety of journals, including Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, Journal of Abnormal and Social Psychology, Personnel Psychology, and Public Opinion Quarterly. Katz was an adviser to the John Wiley Company psychology section during the 1960s and early 1970s, serving as editor of the publisher's Foundations of Social Psychology series.

Katz was active in several professional organizations, including the American Psychological Association, the Industrial Relations Research Association, the Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues, and the Organization for Comparative Social Relations. On his retirement from the University of Michigan in May 1974, Katz was named Professor Emeritus of Psychology.
Katz died February 28, 1998 in Ann Arbor, Michigan.

scopecontent.p: Daniel Katz's papers document his research and teaching activities from 1925 to 1997. His papers reflect the major issues and trends in social psychology, from its early development through its edification as a discipline. The development of Katz's thinking and work is illuminated through his extensive correspondence with contemporaries, articles and other publications, and research materials.

The Katz collection is divided into nine series: Personal; Professional Correspondence; Office of War Information; Professional organizations and related; Research and Surveys; Teaching and course materials; Articles; Published/Unpublished Materials; and Topical Files.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:

scopecontent.p: Biographical information and photographs of Katz are in the Personal series (1926-1995), as are Katz's notes as a student at Syracuse University.

did.unittitle: Syracuse University, Notes from "Social Seminar," circa 1926-1928

scopecontent.p: Professional Correspondence is divided into one chronological subseries and three topical subseries. The dates of the files within this series overlap because the materials were received from different sources at different times. The series documents Katz's involvement with professional organizations and his relationship with other colleagues. Katz maintained correspondence with a number of prominent social psychologists. He considered Floyd H. Allport his mentor and also exchanged personal letters with Professor Edwin Holt, who taught at Princeton. Correspondence with Richard Schanck documents one of Katz's early collaborations with a colleague.

Katz's correspondence as an editor for John Wiley provides a sense of social psychology's development as a discipline, particularly during the 1960s. His critiques of colleagues' manuscripts serve to document the changing directions and priorities of an evolving social science. The Society for the Psychological Study of Social Issues files include discussions by Katz and others about the role which social scientists should -- or should not -- play in becoming actively involved in social issues of the day. Of particular interest is the Herbert Kelman file, which documents Katz's defense of a friend and colleague who was denied a Fulbright fellowship in 1959 due to his pacifist views.

Vallance, Ted 1951-1952 (regarding How Psychological Warfare Works)

scopecontent.p: The Office of War Information series (1942-1944) is comprised of materials from Katz's tenure as the director of research at that department. It includes the raw data, reports, code books, and surveys themselves from a range of studies concerning public perception of World War II.

The Professional organizations and related series documents Katz's participation in various professional conferences and the awards he received from different organizations. Of particular interest are transcripts from interviews with Katz about his career and the founding of the Institute for Social Research.

did.unittitle: American Academy of Arts and Sciences 1989
American Association for Public Opinion Research (AAPOR) 1985
Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, Fellowship 1960-1961

International Public Opinion Research (IPOR) Conference in Paris 1952
National Conference of Christians and Jews Symposium 1955
Veraff, Joseph, Oral History of ISR undated

scopecontent.p: Katz's diverse research interests are evident in the Research and Surveys series. The series contains research papers by Katz, surveys he designed, research grant proposals, and correspondence with colleagues and former students regarding research in progress. At the broadest level, Katz was interested in relations between national and ethnic groups, and in people's attitudes towards social change; a synopsis of Katz's research objectives may be found in the "National Science Foundation Grant" research proposal.

The records in this series also show how Katz adapted his interests to a variety of situations: desegregation in the United States, voting patterns in Denmark and Norway, ethnicity in Yugoslavia. The surveys indicate how public opinion polls were developed, the types of questions which were asked, and in the case of the "National Role Project (Yugoslavia)," how raw survey data was interpreted.

scopecontent.p: Katz's role as professor is documented in the Teaching and course materials series, where exams, handwritten lecture notes, and syllabi are available.

scopecontent.p: Dated articles in the Writings and Lectures series (1927-1997) are arranged chronologically; those undated are in alphabetical order, as are lectures. Note that Katz's numerous book reviews and editorials are compiled into folders and are dated by the earliest document. Many of this collection's articles are co-written, but additional authors are not noted here. Also included is a bibliography for materials published before 1980.

scopecontent.p: Katz may have drawn upon his Topical Files (undated) for class lectures, as well. This collection contains a sample of Katz's extensive, though often illegible and scattered, topical notes. The contents in the first third of these folders were not appraised, reflecting the state of Katz's working files, while illegible materials were removed from the rest.
